<p><font color=#000000><small><hr color=#000000 noshade align=center width=96 size=0></small></font></p>
</div>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>Indicate by check mark whether the registrants (1)&nbsp;have filed all reports required to be filed by Section&nbsp;13 or 15(d) of the Securities Exchange Act of 1934 during the preceding 12&nbsp;months (or for such shorter period that the registrants were required to file such reports) and (2)&nbsp;have been subject to such filing requirements for the past 90&nbsp;days. Yes&nbsp;<font face="Wingdings 2">&#084;</font>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;No&nbsp;<font face="Wingdings 2">&#163;</font></font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>As of October&nbsp;14, 2004, Public Service Enterprise Group Incorporated had outstanding 237,711,750 shares of its sole class of Common Stock, without par value.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>As of October&nbsp;14, 2004, Public Service Electric and Gas Company had issued and outstanding 132,450,344 shares of Common Stock, without nominal or par value, all of which were privately held, beneficially and of record by Public Service Enterprise Group Incorporated.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>PSEG Power LLC and PSEG Energy Holdings LLC are wholly-owned subsidiaries of Public Service Enterprise Group Incorporated and meet the conditions set forth in General Instruction H(1) (a) and (b) of Form&nbsp;10-Q and are filing their respective Quarterly Reports on Form&nbsp;10-Q with the reduced disclosure format authorized by General Instruction&nbsp;H.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>Indicate by check mark whether each registrant is an accelerated filer (as defined in Rule&nbsp;12b-2 of the Exchange Act).</font></p>

<p align=center><b><font color=#000000><a name='Forward'>FORWARD-LOOKING STATEMENTS</a></font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>Except for the historical information contained herein, certain of the matters discussed in this report constitute &ldquo;forward-looking statements&rdquo; within the meaning of the Private Securities Litigation Reform Act of 1995. Such forward-looking statements are subject to risks and uncertainties, which could cause actual results to differ materially from those anticipated. Such statements are based on management&#39;s beliefs, as well as assumptions made by and information currently available to management. When used herein, the words &ldquo;will&rdquo;, &ldquo;anticipate&rdquo;, &ldquo;intend&rdquo;, &ldquo;estimate&rdquo;, &ldquo;believe&rdquo;, &ldquo;expect&rdquo;, &ldquo;plan&rdquo;, &ldquo;hypothetical&rdquo;, &ldquo;potential&rdquo;, &ldquo;forecast&rdquo;, &ldquo;projections&rdquo;, variations of such words
and similar expressions are intended to identify forward-looking statements. Public Service Enterprise Group Incorporated (PSEG), Public Service Electric and Gas Company (PSE&amp;G), PSEG Power LLC (Power) and PSEG Energy Holdings LLC (Energy Holdings) undertake no obligation to publicly update or revise any forward-looking statements, whether as a result of new information, future events or otherwise. The following review of factors should not be construed as exhaustive.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>In addition to any assumptions and other factors referred to specifically in connection with such forward-looking statements discussed above, factors that could cause actual results to differ materially from those contemplated in any forward-looking statements include, among others, the following:</font></p>

    <td align=left valign=top><font color=#000000>international developments negatively
      impacting business;</font></td>
  </tr>

<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>Consequently, all of the forward-looking statements made in this report are qualified by these cautionary statements and none of PSEG, PSE&amp;G, Power and Energy Holdings can assure you that the results or developments anticipated by management will be realized, or even if realized, will have the expected consequences to, or effects on PSEG, PSE&amp;G, Power and Energy Holdings or their respective business prospects, financial condition or results of operations. Undue reliance should not be placed on these forward-looking statements in making any investment decision. Each of PSEG, PSE&amp;G, Power and Energy Holdings expressly disclaim any obligation or undertaking to release publicly any updates or revisions to these forward-looking statements to reflect events or circumstances that occur or arise or are anticipated to
occur or arise after the date hereof. In making any investment decision regarding PSEG&#39;s, PSE&amp;G&#39;s, Power&#39;s and Energy Holdings&#39; securities, PSEG, PSE&amp;G, Power and Energy Holdings are not making, and you should not infer, any representation about the likely existence of any particular future set of facts or circumstances. The forward-looking statements contained in this report are intended to qualify for the safe harbor provisions of Section 27A of the Securities Act of 1933, as amended, and Section 21E of the Securities Exchange Act of 1934, as amended.</font></p>

<p style="page-break-before: always">


<PAGE>
<p align=center><b><font color=#000000><a name='Notes'>NOTES TO CONDENSED CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL STATEMENTS</a><br>
(UNAUDITED)</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>This combined Form 10-Q is separately filed by Public Service Enterprise Group Incorporated (PSEG), Public Service Electric and Gas Company (PSE&amp;G), PSEG Power LLC (Power) and PSEG Energy Holdings LLC (Energy Holdings). Information contained herein relating to any individual company is filed by such company on its own behalf. PSE&amp;G, Power and Energy Holdings each make representations only as to itself and make no representations as to any other company.</font></p>
<p align=left><b><font color=#000000><a name='Note 1'>Note 1. Organization and Basis of Presentation</a></font></b></p>
<p align=left><b><font color=#000000>Organization</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b><font color=#000000>PSEG</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>PSEG has four principal direct wholly-owned subsidiaries: PSE&amp;G, Power, Energy Holdings and PSEG Services Corporation (Services).</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b><font color=#000000>PSE&amp;G</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>PSE&amp;G is an operating public utility company engaged principally in the transmission and distribution of electric energy and natural gas service in certain areas of New Jersey. PSE&amp;G is subject to regulation by the New Jersey Board of Public Utilities (BPU) and the Federal Energy Regulatory Commission (FERC).</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>PSE&amp;G also owns PSE&amp;G Transition Funding LLC (Transition Funding), a bankruptcy remote entity that purchased certain intangible transition property from PSE&amp;G and issued certain transition bonds secured by such property.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b><font color=#000000>Power</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>Power is a multi-regional wholesale energy supply business that utilizes energy trading to comprehensively manage its portfolio of electric generation assets, gas supply and storage contracts and electric and natural gas supply obligations. Power has three principal direct wholly-owned subsidiaries: PSEG Nuclear LLC (Nuclear), PSEG Fossil LLC (Fossil) and PSEG Energy Resources &amp; Trade LLC (ER&amp;T). Nuclear and Fossil own and operate generation and generation-related facilities. ER&amp;T is responsible for the day-to-day management of the portfolio. Fossil, Nuclear and ER&amp;T are subject to regulation by the FERC.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b><font color=#000000>Energy Holdings</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>Energy Holdings has two principal direct wholly-owned subsidiaries: PSEG Global LLC (Global), which owns and operates international and domestic projects engaged in the generation and distribution of energy, including independent power production facilities and electric distribution companies; and PSEG Resources LLC (Resources), which has primarily invested in energy-related leveraged leases. Energy Holdings also owns Enterprise Group Development Corporation (EGDC), a commercial real estate property management business. During the third quarter of 2003, Energy Holdings completed the sale of PSEG Energy Technologies Inc. (Energy Technologies). For additional information relating to Energy Technologies, see Note&nbsp;4. Discontinued Operations, Dispositions and Acquisitions.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b><font color=#000000>Services</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>Services provides management and administrative services to PSEG and its subsidiaries. These include accounting, legal, communications, human resources, information technology, treasury and financial services, investor relations, stockholder services, real estate, environmental, health and safety, insurance, risk management, tax, library and information services, security, corporate secretarial and certain planning, budgeting and forecasting services. Services charges PSEG and its subsidiaries for the</font></p>
<p align=center>17</p>
<p><hr color=#000000 noshade></p>
<p style="page-break-before: always">


<PAGE>
<p align=center><b><font color=#000000>NOTES TO CONDENSED CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL STATEMENTS<br>
(UNAUDITED)</font></b></p>
<p align=left><font color=#000000>cost of work performed and services provided pursuant to the terms and conditions of intercompany service agreements.</font></p>
<p align=left><b><font color=#000000>Basis of Presentation</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b><font color=#000000>PSEG, PSE&amp;G, Power and Energy Holdings</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>The respective financial statements included herein have been prepared pursuant to the rules and regulations of the Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC) for Quarterly Reports on Form&nbsp;10-Q. Certain information and note disclosures normally included in financial statements prepared in accordance with generally accepted accounting principles (GAAP) have been condensed or omitted pursuant to such rules and regulations. These Condensed Consolidated Financial Statements and Notes to Condensed Consolidated Financial Statements (Notes) should be read in conjunction with, and update and supplement matters discussed in PSEG&#39;s, PSE&amp;G&#39;s, Power&#39;s and Energy Holdings&#39; respective Annual Report on Form&nbsp;10-K for the period ended December&nbsp;31, 2003 and Quarterly Reports on Form&nbsp;10-Q for the quarters
ended March&nbsp;31, 2004 and June&nbsp;30, 2004.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>The unaudited condensed consolidated financial information furnished herein reflects all adjustments, which are, in the opinion of management, necessary to fairly state the results for the interim periods presented. All such adjustments are of a normal recurring nature. The year-end Condensed Consolidated Balance Sheets were derived from the audited Consolidated Financial Statements included in the Annual Report on Form&nbsp;10-K for the period ended December&nbsp;31, 2003. Certain reclassifications of prior period data have been made to conform with the current presentation.</font></p>
<p align=left><b><font color=#000000>Pension and Other Postretirement Benefits (OPEB)</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b><font color=#000000>PSEG</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>PSEG sponsors several qualified and nonqualified pension plans and OPEB plans covering PSEG and its participating affiliates&#39; current and former employees who meet certain eligibility criteria.</font></p>

<p align=left><b><font color=#000000>Stock Compensation</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b><font color=#000000>PSEG</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>PSEG applies Accounting Principles Board (APB) Opinion No.&nbsp;25, &ldquo;Accounting for Stock Issued to Employees,&rdquo; and related interpretations in accounting for stock-based compensation plans. Accordingly, no compensation has been recognized for fixed stock option grants since the exercise price of the stock options equaled the market price of the underlying stock on the date of grant. In addition to fixed stock option grants, PSEG also grants restricted stock and performance units to certain key executives. Compensation expense on the restricted stock plan is recorded ratably over the life of the plan. For performance units, compensation expense is measured and recognized once it can be determined that the performance goals will be achieved.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>The following table illustrates the effect on Net Income and Earnings Per Share if PSEG had applied the fair value recognition provisions of Statement of Financial Accounting Standards (SFAS) No.&nbsp;123, &ldquo;Accounting for Stock-Based Compensation,&rdquo; to stock-based employee compensation:</font></p>
<table width=100% cellpadding=0 cellspacing=0 border=0><tr bgcolor=#ffffff>
<td bgcolor=#ffffff>&nbsp;</td>
<td bgcolor=#ffffff>&nbsp;</td>
<td bgcolor=#ffffff>&nbsp;</td>
<td align=center valign=bottom colspan=7><b><font color=#000000><small>Quarters<br>
Ended<br>
September 30,<br>
<hr color=#000000 noshade size=1></small></font></b></td>
<td bgcolor=#ffffff>&nbsp;</td>
<td align=center valign=bottom colspan=7><b><font color=#000000><small>Nine Months<br>

<p align=center><b><font color=#000000>NOTES TO CONDENSED CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL STATEMENTS<br>
(UNAUDITED)</font></b></p>
<p align=left><b><font color=#000000>Goodwill and Other Intangible Assets</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b><font color=#000000>PSEG, PSE&amp;G, Power and Energy Holdings</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>On January 1, 2002, PSEG, PSE&amp;G, Power and Energy Holdings adopted SFAS No.&nbsp;142, &ldquo;Goodwill and Other Intangible Assets&rdquo; (SFAS&nbsp;142). Under this standard, PSEG, PSE&amp;G, Power and Energy Holdings were required to complete an impairment analysis of goodwill. Under SFAS&nbsp;142, goodwill is a nonamortizable asset subject to an annual review for impairment and an interim review when certain events or changes in circumstances occur.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b><font color=#000000>Power and Energy Holdings</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>As of September 30, 2004 and December&nbsp;31, 2003, Power&#39;s and Energy Holdings&#39; recorded goodwill and pro-rata share of goodwill in equity method investments were as follows:</font></p>

<PAGE>
<p align=center><b><font color=#000000>NOTES TO CONDENSED CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL STATEMENTS<br>
(UNAUDITED)</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b><font color=#000000>PSEG, PSE&amp;G, Power and Energy Holdings</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>In addition to goodwill, as of September&nbsp;30, 2004 and December&nbsp;31, 2003, PSEG, PSE&amp;G, Power, Energy Holdings and Services had the following recorded intangible assets:</font></p>
<table width=100% cellpadding=0 cellspacing=0 border=0><tr bgcolor=#ffffff>
<td bgcolor=#ffffff>&nbsp;</td>
<td bgcolor=#ffffff>&nbsp;</td>
<td align=center valign=bottom colspan=3><b><font color=#000000><small>PSE&amp;G<br>
<hr color=#000000 noshade size=1></small></font></b></td>

<div align=left>
<p><font color=#000000><hr color=#000000 noshade align=left width=48 size=0></font></p>
</div>
<p align=left><font color=#000000>(A)&nbsp;Not subject to amortization.</font></p>
<p align=left><font color=#000000>(B)&nbsp;Expensed when used or sold.</font></p>
<p align=left><font color=#000000>(C)&nbsp;Amortized on a straight-line basis.</font></p>
<p align=left><b><font color=#000000>Nuclear Decommissioning Trust (NDT) Funds</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b><font color=#000000>Power</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>Power maintains an independent external trust to provide for decommissioning of its nuclear facilities upon termination of operation. The trust contains two separate funds: a qualified fund and a nonqualified fund. Power&#39;s policy restricts the trust from investing directly in securities or other obligations of PSEG or its affiliates, or its successors or assigns, and from investing in securities of any entity owning one or more nuclear power plants. During the second quarter of 2004, Power moved to a yield-based strategy for its nonqualified fund to take advantage of a lower tax rate. This change resulted in the realization of gains during the second and third quarters of 2004. See Note 11. Other Income and Deductions for additional information.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>The fair value of the NDT Funds was approximately $1 billion as of September&nbsp;30, 2004, which includes stocks, bonds and short-term investments.</font></p>
<p align=left><b><font color=#000000><a name='Note 2'>Note 2. Restatement of Financial Statements</a></font></b></p>
<p align=left><b><font color=#000000>PSEG and Energy Holdings</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>Subsequent to the issuance of the Condensed Consolidated Financial Statements for the quarter ended September&nbsp;30, 2003 and in preparation of the Consolidated Financial Statements for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2003, management determined that the recorded amount of Energy Holdings&#39; investment in RGE was overstated due to a miscalculation of the amount of foreign currency translation adjustments and that certain amounts related to this investment had been erroneously recorded as translation adjustments instead of foreign currency transaction adjustments. The impact on previously reported Net Income of PSEG and Energy Holdings of the adjustments related to RGE resulted in no change for the quarter ended September&nbsp;30, 2003 and a $4&nbsp;million increase for the nine months ended September&nbsp;30, 2003.
As a result, the accompanying Condensed Consolidated Financial Statements of</font></p>
<p align=center>21</p>
<p><hr color=#000000 noshade></p>
<p style="page-break-before: always">


<PAGE>
<p align=center><b><font color=#000000>NOTES TO CONDENSED CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL STATEMENTS<br>
(UNAUDITED)</font></b></p>
<p align=left><font color=#000000>PSEG and Energy Holdings for the quarter and nine months ended September&nbsp;30, 2003 have been restated from the amounts previously reported to reflect the correct amount of foreign currency translation adjustments and to record the effects of foreign currency transactions in earnings rather than as an adjustment to Accumulated Other Comprehensive Loss. In addition to the adjustments described above, certain other adjustments, previously not considered to be material individually and in the aggregate, were also recorded in the restated Condensed Consolidated Financial Statements for the quarter and nine months ended September&nbsp;30, 2003. The impact on previously reported Net Income of PSEG and Energy Holdings of these additional adjustments resulted in a decrease of $3&nbsp;million and an increase of $1 million for the quarter and nine months ended September&nbsp;30,
2003, respectively.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>The effects on the financial statements of all adjustments and their related tax effects are detailed as follows:</font></p>

</table>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>The amounts as previously reported do not reflect certain reclassifications due to the presentation of Energy Holdings&#39; investment in Carthage Power Company (CPC), a generating facility in Tunisia, as</font></p>
<p align=center>22</p>
<p><hr color=#000000 noshade></p>
<p style="page-break-before: always">


<PAGE>
<p align=center><b><font color=#000000>NOTES TO CONDENSED CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL STATEMENTS<br>
(UNAUDITED)</font></b></p>
<p align=left><font color=#000000>a discontinued operation, as discussed in Note 4. Discontinued Operations, Dispositions and Acquisitions and the effects of the adoption of Financial Accounting Standards Board (FASB) Interpretation No. (FIN) 46, &ldquo;Consolidation of Variable Interest Entities&rdquo; (FIN 46), as discussed in Note 3. Recent Accounting Standards, and other reclassifications that have been made to conform with the current presentation.</font></p>
<p align=left><b><font color=#000000><a name='Note 3'>Note 3. Recent Accounting Standards</a></font></b></p>
<p align=left><b><font color=#000000>SFAS No. 143, &ldquo;Accounting for Asset Retirement Obligations&rdquo; (SFAS 143)</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b><font color=#000000>PSEG, PSE&amp;G, Power and Energy Holdings</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>Effective January 1, 2003, PSEG, PSE&amp;G, Power and Energy Holdings each adopted SFAS 143. Under SFAS 143, a company must initially recognize the fair value of a liability for an asset retirement obligation in the period in which it is incurred and concurrently capitalize an asset retirement cost by increasing the carrying amount of the related long-lived asset by the same amount as the liability. A company is required to subsequently depreciate that asset retirement cost to expense over its useful life. In periods subsequent to the initial measurement, a company is required to recognize changes in the liability resulting from the passage of time (accretion) or due to revisions to either the timing or the amount of the originally estimated cash flows. Changes in the liability due to accretion are charged to Operation
and Maintenance expense on the Condensed Consolidated Statements of Operations, whereas changes due to the timing or amount of cash flows are adjustments to the carrying amount of the related asset.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b><font color=#000000>PSEG and Power</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>As a result of adopting SFAS 143, PSEG and Power recorded a Cumulative Effect of a Change in Accounting Principle of $370 million, after-tax, in the first quarter of 2003. Of this after-tax amount, $292 million related to nuclear decommissioning and $78 million related to the reversal of cost of removal liabilities for Power&#39;s fossil units.</font></p>
<p align=left><b><font color=#000000>FIN 46R and FIN 46</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b><font color=#000000>PSEG, PSE&amp;G, Power and Energy Holdings</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>FASB Interpretation No. 46 (revised December 2003), &ldquo;Consolidation of Variable Interest Entities (VIEs)&rdquo;, (FIN&nbsp;46R) amended FIN&nbsp;46 and clarified the application of Accounting Research Bulletin No.&nbsp;51, &ldquo;Consolidated Financial Statements&rdquo; to certain entities in which equity investors do not have sufficient equity at risk for the entity to finance its activities without additional subordinated financial support.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>PSEG, PSE&amp;G, Power and Energy Holdings adopted the provisions of FIN 46 as of July 1, 2003. There was no effect on Power due to the adoption of these rules. The adoption of FIN 46R did not impact the implementation of FIN 46 by PSEG, PSE&amp;G, Power and Energy Holdings or have any other effect on their respective financial statements.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>The adoption of FIN 46 in 2003 required PSEG and PSE&amp;G to deconsolidate their capital trusts and Energy Holdings to consolidate its investments in four real estate partnerships. Prior period financial statements have been restated for comparability in accordance with FIN 46.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b><font color=#000000>PSEG</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>PSEG&#39;s Condensed Consolidated Balance Sheets reflect its equity investment in the capital trusts, which were previously eliminated in consolidation resulting in recording equal amounts of additional</font></p>
<p align=center>23</p>
<p><hr color=#000000 noshade></p>
<p style="page-break-before: always">


<PAGE>
<p align=center><b><font color=#000000>NOTES TO CONDENSED CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL STATEMENTS<br>
(UNAUDITED)</font></b></p>
<p align=left><font color=#000000>assets and liabilities of $36 million as of September&nbsp;30, 2004 and December&nbsp;31, 2003. The invested cash was loaned back to PSEG in connection with the issuance of the preferred securities.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>The following table displays the securities, and their original issuance amounts, held by the trusts that have been deconsolidated.</font></p>

<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>PSEG now records interest expense (previously eliminated against the interest income of the trust) instead of preferred securities dividends (since the preferred dividends are paid by the trusts that are no longer consolidated). For PSEG, these amounts totaled $14 million for each of the quarters ended September&nbsp;30, 2004 and 2003 and $42 million for each of the nine-month periods ended September&nbsp;30, 2004 and 2003.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b><font color=#000000>PSE&amp;G</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>In December 2003, PSE&amp;G redeemed its trust preferred securities. The capital trusts related to the securities were deconsolidated when FIN 46 was adopted in 2003. For PSE&amp;G, interest expense related to these trusts totaled $3 million and $9 million for the quarter and nine months ended September&nbsp;30, 2003, respectively.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>In addition, PSE&amp;G reviewed its Non-Utility Generation (NUG) contracts to determine if the entities involved were VIEs and, if so, if PSE&amp;G was the primary beneficiary. These entities own power plants that sell their output to PSE&amp;G, which PSE&amp;G is contractually obligated to purchase at a variable price that correlates with certain major operating costs of the plants. As a result, PSE&amp;G assumes some of the variability inherent in the operation of these plants.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>PSE&amp;G attempted to obtain the information necessary to conduct the analysis of the cash flow variability required under FIN&nbsp;46R from two facility owners where PSE&amp;G held a potentially significant variable interest, as defined in FIN&nbsp;46R, based on the NUG contracts. The respective facility owners did not provide the information based on their respective belief that the data was competitive and proprietary. As a result, PSE&amp;G is unable to determine whether these entities should be consolidated under FIN&nbsp;46R and applies the scope exception in FIN&nbsp;46R that exempts entities that conduct exhaustive unsuccessful efforts to obtain the necessary information.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>PSE&amp;G incurred energy costs related to these two specific NUG contracts of approximately $1 million for each of the quarters ended September&nbsp;30, 2004 and 2003 and approximately $4 million and $6 million for the nine months ended September&nbsp;30, 2004 and 2003, respectively. PSE&amp;G sells the electricity purchased under all of its NUG contracts at market prices in the PJM Interconnection, L.L.C. (PJM) spot market and recovers the difference between the variable contract price and market price through the Non-Utility Generation Market Transition Charge (NTC).</font></p>
<p align=center>24</p>
<p><hr color=#000000 noshade></p>
<p style="page-break-before: always">


<PAGE>
<p align=center><b><font color=#000000>NOTES TO CONDENSED CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL STATEMENTS<br>
(UNAUDITED)</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b><font color=#000000>Energy Holdings</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>Energy Holdings evaluated its interests in four real estate partnerships previously accounted for under the equity method of accounting. Management determined that these entities were VIEs and further determined that Energy Holdings was the primary beneficiary and, therefore, was required to consolidate these entities. The current presentation reflects these entities on a fully consolidated basis and all prior periods were restated in accordance with FIN&nbsp;46.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>The consolidation of the real estate partnerships on the Condensed Consolidated Balance Sheets resulted in an increase of approximately $31 million in assets and liabilities. There was no material impact of consolidating the real estate partnerships on Operating Revenues or Operating Expenses.</font></p>
<p align=left><b><font color=#000000>Emerging Issues Task Force (EITF) Issue No. 03-11, &ldquo;Reporting Realized Gains and Losses on Derivative Instruments That Are Subject to FASB Statement No. 133,&rdquo; &ldquo;Accounting for Derivative Instruments and Hedging Activities&rdquo;, and Not &ldquo;Held for Trading Purposes&rdquo; as Defined in EITF Issue No.&nbsp;02-3, &ldquo;Issues Involved in Accounting for Derivative Contracts Held for Trading Purposes and Contracts Involved in Energy Trading and Risk Management Activities&rdquo; (EITF&nbsp;03-11)</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b><font color=#000000>PSEG and Power</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>The EITF has previously discussed the income statement presentation of gains and losses on contracts held for trading purposes in EITF Issue No.&nbsp;02-3, &ldquo;Issues Involved in Accounting for Derivative Contracts Held for Trading Purposes and Contracts Involved in Energy Trading and Risk Management Activities&rdquo; (EITF&nbsp;02-3). In its discussion of EITF&nbsp;03-11, the EITF reached a consensus that gains and losses (realized and unrealized) on all derivative instruments within the scope of FASB Statement No.&nbsp;133, &ldquo;Accounting for Derivative Instruments and Hedging Activities&rdquo; (SFAS&nbsp;133) should be shown net when recognized in the Consolidated Statement of Operations, whether or not settled physically, if the derivative instruments are &ldquo;held for trading purposes&rdquo; as defined in EITF&nbsp;02-3.
These rules, which are effective for transactions occurring after September&nbsp;30, 2003, required PSEG and Power to reduce Operating Revenues and Energy Costs by approximately $92 million and $174 million for the quarter and nine months ended September&nbsp;30, 2004, respectively, since these transactions are required to be recorded as net revenue.</font></p>
<p align=left><b><font color=#000000>EITF Issue No. 03-1, &ldquo;The Meaning of Other-Than-Temporary Impairment and Its Application to Certain Investments&rdquo; (EITF&nbsp;03-1)</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b><font color=#000000>PSEG, PSE&amp;G, Power and Energy Holdings</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>EITF 03-1 further defines the meaning of an &ldquo;other-than-temporary impairment&rdquo; and its application to debt and equity securities. Impairment occurs when the fair value of a security is less than its cost basis. When such a condition exists, the investor is required to evaluate whether the impairment is other-than-temporary as defined in EITF&nbsp;03-1. When an impairment is other-than-temporary, the unrealized loss must be charged to earnings.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>On September&nbsp;30, 2004, the FASB issued FASB Staff Position (FSP) EITF&nbsp;03-1-1, &ldquo;Effective date of Paragraphs&nbsp;10-20 of EITF Issue No.&nbsp;03-1, The Meaning of Other-Than-Temporary Impairment and Its Application to Certain Investments&rdquo; (FSP EITF&nbsp;03-1-1). FSP EITF&nbsp;03-1-1 delayed the effective date for the measurement and recognition guidance contained in EITF&nbsp;03-1 until further implementation guidance is issued.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>EITF&nbsp;03-1, when fully adopted, could materially impact the accounting for the investments held in Nuclear Decommissioning Trust Funds. The ultimate impact to PSEG and its subsidiaries cannot be determined until the FASB issues final guidance.</font></p>
<p align=center>25</p>
<p><hr color=#000000 noshade><p></p>
<p style="page-break-before: always">


<PAGE>
<p align=center><b><font color=#000000>NOTES TO CONDENSED CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL STATEMENTS<br>
(UNAUDITED)</font></b></p>
<p align=left><b><font color=#000000>FSP No. 106-2, &ldquo;Accounting and Disclosure Requirements Related to the Medicare Prescription Drug, Improvement and Modernization Act of 2003&rdquo; (FSP 106-2)</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b><font color=#000000>PSEG, PSE&amp;G, Power and Energy Holdings</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>FSP 106-2
  provides guidance on the accounting for the effects of the Medicare Prescription
  Drug, Improvement and Modernization Act of 2003 (Medicare Drug Act) for employers
  who sponsor postretirement health care plans that provide prescription drug
  benefits. FSP&nbsp;106-2 also requires those employers to provide certain disclosures
  regarding the effect of the federal subsidy provided by the Medicare Drug Act.
  The Medicare Drug Act generally permits plan sponsors that provide retiree prescription
  drug benefits that are &ldquo;actuarially equivalent&rdquo; to the benefits
  of Medicare Part D to be eligible for a non-taxable federal subsidy. FSP&nbsp;106-2
  is effective for periods beginning after June 15, 2004. PSEG selected the prospective
  method of adoption of FSP&nbsp;106-2. Upon adoption of FSP 106-2, the subsidy
  reduced the accumulated postretirement benefit obligation by $45 million from
  $929&nbsp;million to $884&nbsp;million on July 1, 2004 and therefore reduces
  future periodic OPEB expense. There was no impact on PSEG&#39;s, PSE&amp;G&#39;s,
  Power&#39;s or Energy Holdings&#39; Condensed Consolidated Financial Statements.</font></p>
<p align=left><b><font color=#000000><a name='Note 4'>Note 4. Discontinued Operations, Dispositions and Acquisitions</a></font></b></p>
<p align=left><b><font color=#000000>Energy Holdings</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b><font color=#000000>Discontinued Operations</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<i><b><font color=#000000>CPC</font></b></i></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>In December 2003, Global entered into a definitive purchase and sale agreement related to the sale of its majority interest in CPC, which owns and operates a power plant located in Rades, Tunisia. In May 2004, Global completed the sale of its majority interest in CPC for approximately $43 million in cash. The assets sold consisted primarily of accounts receivable, property, plant and equipment and other assets. The buyer also assumed certain accounts payable, accrued liabilities and debt obligations.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>In December 2003, Global recognized an estimated loss on disposal of $23 million for the initial write-down of its carrying amount of CPC to its fair value less cost to sell. During the first quarter of 2004, Energy Holdings re-evaluated the carrying value of CPC&#39;s assets and liabilities and determined that an additional write-down to fair value of $2 million was required, offsetting the $2 million of income from operations of CPC during the first quarter of 2004. In May 2004, the actual loss on the sale of CPC totaled $18 million. Global recognized a gain on disposal of $5 million in the second quarter of 2004. Accordingly, the accompanying Condensed Consolidated Statement of Operations for the nine months ended September&nbsp;30, 2004 includes a gain on disposal of $3 million.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>The operating results of CPC for the quarters and nine months ended September&nbsp;30, 2004 and 2003 are summarized below:</font></p>
<table width=100% cellpadding=0 cellspacing=0 border=0><tr bgcolor=#ffffff>

<td align=center valign=top colspan=15><b><font color=#000000><small>(Millions)</small></font></b></td></tr>

<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<i><b><font color=#000000>Energy Technologies&#39; Investments</font></b></i></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>In June 2002, Energy Holdings adopted a plan to sell its heating, ventilating and air conditioning (HVAC)/mechanical operating companies. The HVAC/mechanical operating companies met the criteria for classification as components of Discontinued Operations. During the first quarter of 2003, Energy Holdings re-evaluated the carrying value of Energy Technologies&#39; assets and liabilities and determined that an additional write-down to fair value of $9 million, net of a $3 million tax benefit, was required. The sale of the HVAC/mechanical operating companies and Energy Technologies was complete as of September&nbsp;30, 2003.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>The operating results of Energy Technologies for the quarter and nine months ended September&nbsp;30, 2003 were as follows:</font></p>

<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b><font color=#000000>Dispositions</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<i><b><font color=#000000>Meiya Power Company Limited (MPC)</font></b></i></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>For information related to MPC, see Note 16. Subsequent Events.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<i><b><font color=#000000>LDS</font></b></i></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>In April 2004, Global sold a portion of its shares in LDS, in the Lima stock exchange, reducing its ownership from 44% to 38% and received gross proceeds of approximately $31 million. Global realized an after-tax gain of approximately $5 million in the second quarter of 2004 related to the LDS sale. The gain is recorded in Income from Equity Method Investments on the Condensed Consolidated Statements of Operations.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<i><b><font color=#000000>Resources</font></b></i></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>In March 2004, Resources entered an agreement with Midwest Generation LLC, an indirect subsidiary of Edison Mission Energy (EME), to terminate its lease investment in the Collins generating facility in Illinois. In April 2004, Resources closed on the termination of the lease agreement and received gross proceeds of approximately $184 million (approximately $84 million, after-tax) that allowed it to substantially recover its carrying value in this lease. In connection with the agreement, in</font></p>
<p align=center>27</p>
<p><hr color=#000000 noshade></p>
<p style="page-break-before: always">


<PAGE>
<p align=center><b><font color=#000000>NOTES TO CONDENSED CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL STATEMENTS<br>
(UNAUDITED)</font></b></p>
<p align=left><font color=#000000>the first quarter of 2004, Resources recorded an unrealized loss of $17 million, after-tax, related to the termination of the lease.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>In January 2004, Resources terminated two lease transactions because the lessees exercised their purchase option. Resources received aggregate cash proceeds of approximately $45 million, recognizing an after-tax gain of $4 million. As a result of these lease terminations, Resources paid income taxes of $36 million in 2004.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b><font color=#000000>Acquisitions</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<i><b><font color=#000000>Texas Independent Energy, L.P. (TIE)</font></b></i></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>In June
  2004, Global notified TECO Energy, Inc. (TECO) of its intent to convert a fractional
  amount of its preferred interest in TIE and thereby gain majority control of
  TIE. In July 2004, Global signed an agreement to acquire all of TECO&#39;s 50%
  equity interest in TIE for less than $1 million. With this purchase, Global
  now owns 100% of TIE and consolidated this investment effective July&nbsp;1,
  2004. As a result, Energy Holdings presents approximately $630 million of Property,
  Plant and Equipment, $72 million of Other Assets, $461 million of Long-Term
  Non-Recourse Debt, and $27 million of Other Liabilities related to TIE on its
  Condensed Consolidated Balance Sheet as of the effective acquisition date.</font></p>

&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Energy Holdings' pro forma consolidated Operating
Revenues for the nine months ended September 30, 2004 had the acquisition of TIE
occurred at the beginning of the year would have increased from $701 million to
$931 million. The pro forma Operating Revenues for the quarter and nine months
ended September 30, 2003 would have increased from $178 million to $319 million
and from $539 million to $903 million, respectively, had the acquisition occurred
at the beginning of 2003. The pro forma information is presented for informational
purposes only and is not necessarily indicative of the results of operations that
actually would have been achieved had the acquisition been consummated as of that
time. This acquisition is expected to be modestly accretive to Energy Holdings'
earnings.
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<i><b><font color=#000000>Electrowina Skawina S.A. (Skawina)</font></b></i></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>In 2002, Global acquired a controlling interest in the electric and thermal coal-fired Skawina plant in Poland. In accordance with the purchase agreement, Global acquired an additional 12% from Skawina&#39;s employees in 2004, increasing its ownership interest to approximately 75%. The transaction required an additional investment of approximately $8 million and closed in the third quarter of 2004. For additional information, see Note 7. Commitments and Contingent Liabilities.</font></p>
<p align=left><b><font color=#000000><a name='Note 5'>Note 5. Extraordinary Item</a></font></b></p>
<p align=left><b><font color=#000000>PSE&amp;G</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>In May 2002,
  PSE&amp;G filed an Electric Base Rate Case with the BPU requesting an annual
  $250 million increase for its electric distribution business. In June 2003,
  a proposed settlement was filed with the Administrative Law Judge (ALJ) who
  recommended approval of the settlement to the BPU. In July 2003, PSE&amp;G received
  an oral decision from the BPU approving the proposed settlement with certain
  modifications. The related Final Order was received on April&nbsp;22, 2004.
  As a result of the oral decision and subsequent summary written order, in the
  second quarter of 2003, PSE&amp;G recorded certain adjustments in connection
  with the resolution of various issues relating to the Final Order PSE&amp;G
  received from the BPU in 1999 relating to PSE&amp;G&#39;s rate unbundling, stranded
  costs and restructuring proceedings. These amounts include a $30 million pre-tax
  refund to customers related to revenues previously collected in rates for nuclear
  decommissioning. Because this amount reflects the final accounting for PSEG&#39;s
  generation-related business pursuant to the four-year transition plan mandated
  by the Final Order, the adjustment has been recorded as an $18 million, after-tax,
  Extraordinary Item as required under APB Opinion No.&nbsp;30, &ldquo;Reporting
  the Results of Operations&mdash;Reporting the Effects of Disposal of a Segment
  of a Business, and Extraordinary, Unusual and Infrequently Occurring Events
  and Transactions&rdquo; and SFAS No. 101, &ldquo;Regulated Enterprises&mdash;Accounting
  for the Discontinuation of Application of FASB Statement No.&nbsp;71&rdquo;.</font></p>
<p align=center>28</p>
<p><hr color=#000000 noshade><p></p>
<p style="page-break-before: always">


<PAGE>
<p align=center><b><font color=#000000>NOTES TO CONDENSED CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL STATEMENTS<br>
(UNAUDITED)</font></b></p>
<p align=left><b><font color=#000000><a name='Note 6'>Note 6. Earnings Per Share (EPS)</a></font></b></p>
<p align=left><b><font color=#000000>PSEG</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>Diluted EPS is calculated by dividing Net Income by the weighted average number of common stock shares outstanding, including shares issuable upon exercise of stock options outstanding under PSEG&#39;s equity compensation plans. The following table shows the effect of these stock options on the weighted average number of shares outstanding used in calculating Diluted EPS:</font></p>

</table>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>There were approximately 5.3 million and 3.3 million stock options excluded from the weighted average common shares calculation used for Diluted EPS due to their antidilutive effect for the quarters ended September&nbsp;30, 2004 and 2003, respectively.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>There were approximately 2.9 million and 6.1 million stock options excluded from the weighted average common shares calculation used for Diluted EPS due to their antidilutive effect for the nine months ended September&nbsp;30, 2004 and 2003, respectively.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>There were approximately 9.2 million participating units excluded from the weighted average common shares calculation used for Diluted EPS due to their antidilutive effect for the nine months ended September&nbsp;30, 2003.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>Dividend payments on common stock for the quarter ended September&nbsp;30, 2004 were $0.55 per share and totaled approximately $131 million. Dividend payments on common stock for the nine months ended September&nbsp;30, 2004 were $1.65 per share and totaled approximately $391 million. Dividend payments on common stock for the quarter ended September&nbsp;30, 2003 were $0.54 per share and totaled approximately $122 million. Dividend payments on common stock for the nine months ended September&nbsp;30, 2003 were $1.62 per share and totaled approximately $366 million.</font></p>
<p align=center>29</p>
